articles.name: New in Zendesk Talk: new and updated Talk Stats APIs
articles.title: New in Zendesk Talk: new and updated Talk Stats APIs
articles.body:
We know that our native Talk dashboard can’t fulfill every use case, which is why we’ve updated our Talk Stats APIs to return even more metrics that you can use to build your own custom dashboards.

Here’s what’s changed!

Account Overview endpoint

api/v2/channels/voice/stats/account_overview.json

We’ve created a new endpoint to return all the data necessary for you to get an overview of what’s happening in your Talk account for the current day. This endpoint exposes the metrics that are displayed in the Overview section of the native dashboard. The data is displayed as for the current day and you can filter this endpoint by phone_number_ids.

Agents Overview endpoint

/api/v2/channels/voice/stats/agents_overview.json

We created another new endpoint to show aggregated information of all of your agents. The data is displayed as for the current day.

Agents Activity endpoint

/api/v2/channels/voice/stats/agents_activity.json

We added a bunch of new metrics to this existing endpoint. You can now get more data about your individual agents, as separate to the aggregated data that’s displayed in agents_overview.json. The data is displayed as for the current day and you can filter this endpoint by group_ids. Metrics like {status} are updated in near real-time.

Current Queue Activity endpoint

/api/v2/channels/voice/stats/current_queue_activity.json

This endpoint hasn't gone through any changes but is there for you monitor your current Talk queue in near real-time.

Here's an awesome example of what you can build using our APIs, from our partner Geckoboard.

Developer documentation

You can find documentation on all Talk endpoints on developer.zendesk.com.

Availability

The endpoints are accessible to customers on Talk Team, Professional and Enterprise plans. You’ll be able to view the keys that are applicable to your plan in each endpoint.

Deprecation notice

As part of this announcement we’d also like to announce the deprecation of /api/v2/channels/voice/stats/historical_queue_activity.json. The information returned in this endpoint is now made obsolete with the release of account_overview.json and it will be formally removed on November 24th 2017.

After this date you will no longer be able to pull information from the historical_queue_activity.

articles.name: Announcing video embedding in the Guide article editor
articles.title: Announcing video embedding in the Guide article editor
articles.body:
Today we’re happy to announce the ability for customers to easily embed videos from popular video sites into their articles, without accessing the article code or enabling the Display Unsafe Content option.

The video providers we support out of the box are:

  • YouTube
  • Vimeo
  • Wistia
  • JWPlayer
  • Brightcove

In the article editor, you will see a new icon for adding videos.

Clicking this button opens a menu where you can enter the URL of the video that you’d like to embed. After you enter the URL, a preview of the video displays in the modal window.

Then you can click to insert the video in your article. The video is embedded at the cursor in the article body.

When you are ready, you can publish your new video in your Help Center.

articles.name: Announcing JIRA App v4
articles.title: Announcing JIRA App v4
articles.body:
October 20th, 2017

We're excited to announce a redesign of the JIRA app for Zendesk Support. Version 4 adds many long-awaited usability improvements, like the user configurable issue creation form. The app is now also faster, better looking, and more functional.

Main new features

  • Admins can configure which fields appear on the JIRA issue creation form in Support.
  • Keywords search for JIRA issues when from Support.
  • Ticket information can be automatically copied to the issue creation form.
  • Improved performance and usability thanks to the new Zendesk Apps framework.

Configurable issue creation from

There is now an easy way to define which JIRA fields an agent sees when creating a new JIRA issue from Support, a significant enhancement introduced in the JIRA app v4.

These fields are specific to a particular JIRA project and issue type. Issue fields defined as "required" in JIRA will appear on the form regardless of configurations on this form.

Note that only Support admins can configure these fields for their agents.

All existing installations have been updated to the latest version of the JIRA app. No customer action is required.

For information on working with the new app, see Setting up the JIRA for Zendesk Support integration and Using the JIRA for Zendesk Support integration.

FAQ

Q: Can I use both the old app (v3) and the new one (v4) at the same time?

A: App v4 is designed to supersede the previous version. This means that after the upgrade to v4, the previous version will no longer be available.

Q: Do I need to do anything after upgrading to v4?

A: The app will configured automatically and ready to use. Admins can take advantage of the new features like configuring the form fields.

Q: Has any feature been removed from the app v4?

A: The updated app is superset of the previously available features.

It's time for September's Community Roundup!

The Zendesk Community is a busy place, so we've gathered up the month's best posts and discussions to make sure you don't miss anything!

How to make Zendesk emails work for your brand

Trigger recipe: Set priority based on key words in incoming tickets

Restricting Satisfaction Surveys by Date

  • Do your customers often submit multiple tickets? Do you want to make sure they're not overwhelmed with multiple satisfaction surveys? Graeme Carmichael collaborates with fellow Moderator Joel Hellman to show you how to take control of those surveys.

We're excited to announce our first ever Self-Service newsletter will be launching in October! We'll be curating the very best content from Knowledge and Community, inspired by a new theme each month. Sign up below to have this great resource delivered straight to your inbox!

Moderator Showcase

Heather R became a Zendesk Community Moderator on September 12, 2017!

Heather says that Zendesk plays a crucial role in her company’s day-to-day work, in both IT Service Desk and non-service desk departments that interact with the same user base. Her areas of Zendesk expertise include Guide and Support, especially using triggers and macros to customize Zendesk for more than 100 agents representing 4 departments with different preferences and business processes.

More about Heather:

I went on Outward Bound when I was 16, sailing the seas for two weeks in Maine. There is only one sunrise that rivals the Maine sunrise, and that is in Maui. Nothing makes the world sweeter than a cup of coffee in the morning and a smile from my kids. Not necessarily in that order, but maybe. articles.name: Update to end-user behavior
articles.title: Update to end-user behavior
articles.body:
We were made aware of an existing vulnerability in our end user log-in flow, also known as the “Ticket Trick” Vulnerability. This vulnerability would allow hackers to sign up to a company’s help center and use the unverified email provided to access that company’s Yammer or Slack instances.

In an effort to make Zendesk more secure and protect our customers from this vulnerability, end users who were created after September 17, 2017 need to verify their email address to view the tickets they submitted. This fix does not affect accounts that use SAML or JWT for their end user log in, as those users are automatically verified by the identity provider upon sign in.

If end-users have not verified their email address and try to access their requests in Help Center, they'll see the following error with a link to have the email verification resent to them:

For the various methods of verifying an user email address, see this article in the Support Help Center.

We recommend making sure you have the appropriate triggers enabled (for example: "Notify requester of comment update" trigger) to ensure your end users are notified by email when there's an update to their request. For more information on triggers, see Creating and managing triggers for ticket updates and notifications.

articles.name: Zendesk Guide: Announcing the Knowledge Capture app
articles.title: Zendesk Guide: Announcing the Knowledge Capture app
articles.body:
In May we launched an early access program for the Knowledge Capture app, and I want to kick off this announcement by thanking each of you who participated. Your usage and feedback have shaped the Knowledge Capture app into what it is today.

Improving how your teams find, use, improve and create knowledge is something we will continue to improve, and the Knowledge Capture app is a part of that journey.

Today, we are happy to announce the release the Knowledge Capture app as part of Guide Professional. For many of you who are being introduced to Knowledge Capture for the first time, the Knowledge Capture app leverages your support team’s collective knowledge and enables agents link to articles in tickets, create new Help Center content, and flag content for improvements, directly from the Zendesk Support agent interface.

It’s important to note that the Knowledge Capture app is not, nor is it intended to be a KCS certified product. We believe there is a lot of value in the KCS principles and we have focused on unleashing that value with the Knowledge Capture app, but we are not currently checking off a KCS v.6 compliance checklist.

What is the Knowledge Capture app

The app enables your agents to improve knowledge as they go, by capturing collective knowledge and building on it over time to respond to support requests more effectively. Using the app, agents can:

  • Search the Help Center without leaving the ticket
  • Insert links to relevant Help Center articles in ticket comments
  • Associate internal or access restricted articles to a ticket even if they are not sent to your customer
  • Add inline feedback to existing articles that need updates
  • Create new articles while answering tickets, using a pre-defined template
  • Switch language or brand

How to get the Knowledge Capture app

You must have Guide Professional to use the Knowledge Capture app. You must be on Support Professional or Enterprise to use the Knowledge Capture app reporting dashboard.

You can get the app from the Zendesk Apps Marketplace, in the self-service category. The Knowledge Capture app can replace other apps you may have installed, including the Answer Suggestion app and the Ticket to Help Center app.

To install the app and plan your workflows, see:

  • Installing the Knowledge Capture app
  • Workflows for created and flagged articles

To use the app, see:

  • Searching and linking articles
  • Adding feedback to flag articles
  • Creating articles based on tickets
  • Analyzing Knowledge Capture activity

articles.name: Announcing: Revision History for Triggers
articles.title: Announcing: Revision History for Triggers
articles.body:
Rollout complete. As of October 10, 2017, this feature should be available to all Enterprise accounts.

Enterprise customers: now you can see a history of your trigger updates!

We’ve added this capability in order to give you more confidence when updating triggers, and to give you more tools for troubleshooting. It will also provide more accountability, especially for teams where multiple people are updating business rules.

From now on, we'll be keeping track of configuration changes made to your individual triggers. We’ll record who made the change, when it was made, and the exact trigger configuration. You can access that history right from the trigger’s edit page. It’ll be available to anyone with permission to manage business rules.

Just click on the link that appears below the trigger title:

When you get to the history page, you’ll see all the available versions in a sidebar. Click on the one you’re interested in, and here's what you'll see:

For now, just changing the position of a trigger won’t be counted as a revision.

While we won't have history going back before this feature was released, we did include the current version of each trigger as the first recorded version. The revision is listed as having been made “by Zendesk.”

In the coming weeks, we'll be adding some enhancements:

  • The ticket event log will specify which version of a trigger was applied, and link directly to it
  • The URL for each trigger version will be a shareable permanent link
  • We'll flag what changed in a particular version so you can identify differences more easily

If you find this feature valuable, be sure to let us know here in the comments! It’ll help us prioritize adding revision history to other workflow tools, like automations and views.

articles.name: Announcing Zendesk Talk Enterprise
articles.title: Announcing Zendesk Talk Enterprise
articles.body:
The Talk team is excited to announce the launch of Talk Enterprise, our new pricing plan that provides growing teams and call centers with the tools and hands-on support they need to successfully deliver phone support at scale.

Talk Enterprise includes all the features on Talk Professional, plus:

Launch Success Program

Get off on the right with hands-on deployment support from Zendesk experts. The Zendesk team will help companies define business goals, optimize their network and environment, configure their Talk instance and review supervisor features.

Monthly diagnostics

Monthly diagnostics provides a deep-dive on performance and expert guidance to help teams troubleshoot and prevent outages. This service includes (learn more):

  • Diagnostic reports containing actionable information regarding Talk performance, like connection failure causes, terminations errors and network issues
  • Monthly consultative call with a Zendesk Talk expert to review these reports in detail, answer any questions and provide suggestions for system improvements

Usage SLA

The Talk Enterprise Usage SLA covers any outages due to our service provider’s (Twilio) API, which will trigger a usage credit (this credit is applied towards Talk usage, and will not apply the Talk agent license subscription). Learn more.

Failover-on-demand

In the event of a site-specific outage that impacts Talk connectivity, customers may request “failover on-demand” to route calls to an alternate number. Learn more.


As part of the introduction of Talk Enterprise, we’re also announcing an update to our other Talk pricing plans and packages.

As we continue to evolve the Zendesk family of products, it’s important that we align all the different elements of our brand. This includes our plan names. So, we’ve decided to rename the legacy Zendesk Talk plans.

As of September 6th, 2017, Zendesk Talk has the following renamed plans:

  • Lite
  • Team
  • Professional
  • Enterprise

You can view the features available by plan type on the Zendesk Talk pricing page.

FAQs

How do I know which plan I am on?

In general, if you purchased Talk before September 6th, 2017, you will be on the legacy plans.

Already a paying customer? Nothing’s changing for you.

If you’re a paying customer as of September 6th, 2017, the plan and pricing changes do not affect you at all.

You are grandfathered into your existing plan and your current pricing and packaging.

Can I upgrade/downgrade to legacy plans rather than switching to the new plans?

Customers can stay with the plan they are on! You will need to shift to our new plan structure if you choose to upgrade or downgrade plans.

Are you planning to remove the legacy plans?

We are not planning to remove any of our legacy plans from existing customers.

When I come up for renewal, will I be able to stay on my existing plan?

Yes.

What if I want to add/remove agents but not change plans?

As long as you don’t change the plan you are on, you can add or remove as many agents as you like and you will remain on the plan you are on.

Is there a benefit to changing plans?

If you’d like to upgrade to more features and functionality or if you’re not using all the features and functionality of your existing Zendesk plan, then you may want to consider switching to one of our new plans.

articles.name: Support SDK improvements for setting language for new users
articles.title: Support SDK improvements for setting language for new users
articles.body:
When users of your apps interact with the Support SDK for the first time, a user is created in your Zendesk Support account. At the moment, they are created with your account's default language on their user profile.

On the 7th September this will be changing. For some versions of the Support SDK, the language for new users will match their device locale. If we don't support the device's locale (eg. Klingon), then we'll still use your account's default language.

Read on to find out why we are doing this, which versions of the Support SDK are compatible with this change, and what this means for you.

Why make this change?

If you support customers in multiple languages, not knowing the correct language to use for a given customer is a real pain. For example, if you use dynamic content to serve localized versions of frequently used text, an incorrect end-user language can result in a poor customer experience.

We're making this change so that you can take full advantage of features like dynamic content, triggers, and automations.

Which versions of the Support SDK support this change?

Not all versions of the Support SDK are compatible with this change.

  • Android
    • If you are using v1.10.0.1 or higher, this change will take effect.
    • If you are using older versions, end-users will continue to be created using your account's default language.
  • iOS
    • This change will take effect for all versions of the Support SDK.

What does it mean for me?

Users created in Zendesk Support after the 7th September will have the correct language set based on their device's configuration. This means that:

  • You will be able to serve the correct language variants of dynamic content for those users.
  • You will be able to more reliably use the Requester: Language condition in triggers and automations (see image below).

Existing end-users in your Zendesk Support will not be changed. Whatever language is set on their user profile will remain.

Questions

If you have questions about this change, the best place to ask them is in the Mobile SDK community.

articles.name: Introducing Macro Previews
articles.title: Introducing Macro Previews
articles.body:
We've added a fully keyboard navigable experience for agents to quickly preview the content of a macro before applying it to a ticket.

This feature is available to customers with an Enterprise plan.

When will I get Macro Previews on my account?

You'll see this new functionality appear on your account on Thursday, September 14th 2017.

What's not changing?

Accessing macros

Agents will continue to be able to access their macro list using the list at the bottom of a ticket or the keyboard shortcut (ctrl + alt + m). There are not changes in how you access your macro list.

What's Changing?

Preview and Description

As agents hover or focus on a macro in the list, they will see an option to preview the macro. To apply the macro immediately, they can select the macro (keyboard or by hitting 'enter') to apply. Otherwise, they can preview the macro by clicking on the preview icon or using their keyboard (Shift + Enter).

If the macro has a description, they can quickly read the macro description without having to go through any extra steps. For now, if a macro does not have a description, the description tooltip will not appear.

Using the Preview


The macro preview displays all of the fields that this macro will change, add, or remove. This view summarizes what applying the macro will do to the ticket. It displays them in a way that mirrors the ticket layout. Currently, these fields are not editable.

Ticket Fields

If there are a lot of ticket fields, you’ll need to scroll down to view them all like you would in the ticket context. Tag changes are displayed as changes ( + or - ) so that agents can quickly see only what is being added or removed.

Comments

The layout and color of the comment mirrors the ticket. Internal Notes are yellow; Public Comments are white.

Placeholders and Dynamic Content

Agents need to see the content that is exists in placeholders and dynamic content to make the decision of whether or not this is the correct macro to use. You'll notice that both placeholders and dynamic content are rendered in the subject and comment preview so you can see what is being applied.

Attachments

You can see attachments that will be carried over into the ticket.

Title & Description

The description for each macro appears below the title. If an agent has access, they will see prompts to add or edit the description.

Applying the Macro

Agents can use keyboard navigation or click on Apply Macro to apply their changes to a ticket from the preview screen. If an agent decides this is not the correct macro, they can hit “cancel” or "esc" without causing any costly changes to the ticket.

Consistent Layout

The preview layout is consistent with the ticket layout and gives you clues when values don’t exist in a macro. This helps agents quickly understand the content of a macro to compare it to others. In this case, this macro does not change ticket property fields.

In the following case, the macro does not change ticket property fields.

Here, the macro does not add a subject or comment.

articles.name: Zendesk Talk: Announcing Textback from IVR
articles.title: Zendesk Talk: Announcing Textback from IVR
articles.body:
Talk Advanced customers can now add an option to IVR that allows callers to choose Text support instead of waiting for an agent. This provides opportunities for customers to switch channel and to get support in an asynchronous fashion, and for the provision of a menu of items to enable ticket-deflection by texting customers with information or links to articles that they may use to self service their requests.

Selecting Textback creates an SMS ticket, and sends a pre-configured message to the customer allowing for a continued conversation via SMS to be managed in that ticket.

Updated documentation for configuring IVR may be found here and reporting of the number of Textback requests in a day is in the Dashboard.

The really interesting story around the genesis of this feature, coming from our internal Zendevian cup hackathon, is covered in our blog post.

articles.name: Moving to the System Font Stack
articles.title: Moving to the System Font Stack
articles.body:
When will I see this change?

The System Font Stack change is rolling out Wednesday, September 6th to 10% of customers. We're aiming to slowly ramp up to 100% of customers by Wednesday, September, 20th. A rolling release like this allows us to take time to hear feedback and react quickly if needed before the change affects all customers. There's nothing you need to do. Your account will get this update sometime in the next two weeks. We'll be keeping a close eye on feedback so feel free to post any questions or concerns here.

Usability Improvements

With the release of Proxima Nova, there were some notable usability concerns that we wanted to address with this move to system fonts.

Kerning

Both system fonts for Windows OS and Mac OS have fonts that come with kerning by default. Kerning refers to letter spacing that makes wide and thin letters feel much more readable. Some web fonts, like Proxima Nova, required enabling and tweaking of kerning settings.

Proxima Nova

System Font Stack

Readablity

The system fonts typically are thicker than the current Proxima Nova font. This makes it easier to read and highlights the contrast between the text and the background. Though the font is a bit bigger, it won't affect how much information you see on the screen for high touchpoint areas like ticket properties because the container sizes have not changed. Check out this side-by-side comparison of the ticket property fields.


(Left: Proxima Nova; Right: System Font Stack)

Performance Improvements

Because Zendesk Support will be using the System Font Stack, you might experience overall faster font loading compared to using web fonts. How much faster depends on a number of factors, especially your Internet connection, but it is a meaningful amount both in terms of files and bytes. With Proxima Nova, the current web font, we provide many font weights that your computer has to hunt down before it can render the font. When using system fonts, the computer already has everything it needs, so there is zero download time.

What is the System Font Stack?

A font stack is a list of fonts and font keywords used to let a browser know our preferred and fallback fonts. For example, a font stack could be "Helvetica Neue, Arial, sans-serif" which would indicate Helvetica Neue as our most-preferred font (if available), and then Arial (which is on most computers), and lastly a generic sans-serif font, which is vague but guarantees we won’t accidentally show a serif font like Times New Roman.

Web sites have a few different options to choose from when it comes to choosing fonts for that stack:

  • Web safe fonts: These require no download time by the browser so they are fast to render. Most people think these web safe fonts look a bit dated. Examples include Arial, Verdana, and Georgia.
  • Web fonts: These tend to match the feel of a company and look beautiful, but require download by the browser so they are slower to render. They are not pre-installed in your system, instead, the fonts are downloaded by your browser while preparing to render the webpage, and then applied to your text. Additionally, they require a trade-off between skipping less-common characters and forcing larger downloads.
  • System fonts: No download time required! These tend to feel and look good, rendering crisply because they are the font your operating system natively uses for its own user interface. Your computer's system is optimized for this font, which is going to have a very complete set of supported characters.

Using the System Font Stack, we'll be able to serve every individual user the right font for their native operating system. This means faster loading times for fonts and a native font that is easy to read.

What's changing?

We're updating the current font from Proxima Nova, a web font, to the system font stack. Here is how our system font stack looks:

body {font: system-ui, -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, “Segoe UI”, Roboto, Oxygen-Sans, Ubuntu, Cantarell, “Helvetica Neue”, Arial, sans-serif; }

You'll notice this reflected in the entire Support product.

Operating System and Browser Specifics

Windows

While most browsers on Windows OS, including IE and Edge, don’t support a keyword to use the system font, we're still able to match it by including the font “Segoe UI” in our font stack.

macOS

Apple provides a new font keyword, -apple-system, that will resolve to the system font. Today, that is San Francisco. Apple has changed their system font before, and may again one day. When that happens, users on the latest operating system will see that font on websites using the font keyword; users on older systems will still see San Francisco.

Everywhere else

Chrome now supports "system-ui," a font keyword that resolves to the system font on all operating systems (including Windows, Mac, and Linux). More browsers will add this keyword soon. And we’ve included some Linux-specific fonts in our stack in the meantime.

articles.name: New article revisions for Guide's knowledge base
articles.title: New article revisions for Guide's knowledge base
articles.body:
We've launched article revisions! Article revisions in Guide Professional to help you track versions of an article in your knowledge base, so you and your team can more easily keep track and manage content changes. Like Google Docs, it enables you to see who made edits and what updates were made to the article title and body. You can also restore previous versions if something went awry. Combined with the history view feature, article revisions serves up more transparency into the evolution of your knowledge content.

Here’s how article revisions work in your knowledge base:

View revisions for an article

From the article editor, select View revisions. You will see all versions of the article and who made them in the right-hand navigation. When you select each revision, you can see the difference between the selected and previous version. Content that is removed is highlighted in red with a strikethrough, and content that was added is highlighted in green.

Restore a version

If you want to restore a previous version, select the version and click Restore and you’ll be taken back to the article editor with the content from that version. If you select Update, a new version of the article will be saved with the restored version.

Tracking the article history

Article revisions work with the history view to give you the play-by-play on what has been updated and by who. Select Article revisions to jump to the history view scoped to updates for that article. This shows you the full audit history for that article including things like publishing events, author changes, title updates, etc. From history view, you can also jump back to a specific version by clicking on any body or title update links.

See it in action…


Check out the product documentation on Viewing article revisions and history and make sure to follow the Announcement section to be informed when Zendesk launches new features including new features in Guide.

articles.name: Introducing Answer Bot - Automatic article suggestions for better self-service support
articles.title: Introducing Answer Bot - Automatic article suggestions for better self-service support
articles.body:
Today we are excited to introduce our newest Guide feature, Answer Bot, which has been designed to increase self-service efficiency by responding to customer's questions with relevant knowledge base articles from Zendesk Guide.

Using powerful deep learning models, Answer Bot is ready to start working on day one. It can tap into all past experiences across thousands of customers, and apply what it’s learned to your customers and content—even if you don’t have many of either. With Answer Bot, key channels such as Email and API now have the option to offer automatic, immediate self-service capability.

What makes Answer Bot great?

1. It works wherever your customers are: Answer Bot already works across several channels including email and API which typically don’t have great automated self service experiences. We’re also extending Answer Bot to create new in-channel experiences for web form, web widget, chat, and our SDKs in the near future.

2. Activate and go: We’ve removed the complexity to make it as easy as possible for anyone to start using Answer Bot straight away. No training time or massive data sets needed. (You’re wondering how? Because it’s trained on over 12 million customer service interactions to deliver accurate and reliable responses. And it’ll continue to learn and grow.)

3. Learns from customers and agents: Interactions between Answer Bot and your customers are clearly presented to your support team, allowing them to see the actions customers have taken to avoid suggesting the same content again. Your support team can also provide pointers to Answer Bot to help it learn over time.

4. Optimize performance with reporting: Generate insights into where Answer Bot performs well and where you may need to create or improve your knowledge base content.

Getting Started with Answer Bot

Starting today, all Zendesk Guide Professional customers will be able to start their 30-day trial for Answer Bot. In order to use Answer Bot, you must enable it in Zendesk Support. To enable Answer Bot:

  • Click the Admin icon () in the sidebar, then select Business Rules > Answer Bot.
  • Click the Try Answer Bot for 30 days to activate your 30-day trial.
  • Follow the on-screen tips to learn about how Answer Bot works and then start setting up your Triggers, unleashing Answer Bot on your incoming tickets.

There's a whole lot more info on the Answer Bot resources article.

Answer Bot plans and subscription management

Answer Bot is an add-on to Guide and requires Guide Professional or Guide Legacy. Find out more about Guide plans. It's designed to work on any Support plan, however we recommend Support Professional or Enterprise to allow you to access Insights reporting for detailed analysis and performance tracking.

Answer Bot is provided on a usage based subscription model - you can select from a range of monthly resolution limit and only tickets that are solved by Answer Bot count towards that usage limit. A 30 day unlimited trial will allow you fully assess your potential monthly resolutions, to choose the most appropriate limit. Compare all Answer Bot plans and discount tiers

articles.name: Automatic updates for new features suspended for Help Center legacy themes
articles.title: Automatic updates for new features suspended for Help Center legacy themes
articles.body:
We are continually working to keep pace with modern best practices for the web. With the release of our Copenhagen theme for Help Center, we took a step forward. We are now supporting responsive design, accessibility, and other important web standards out of the box when a user starts a new Help Center.

In order for us to stay focused on these standards and the Copenhagen theme, only customers who have a non-customized version of the Copenhagen theme will receive updates automatically.

If you have any of the following themes, you will no longer receive automatic updates for new features on these themes:

  • The Wiry Merchant
  • The Curious Wind
  • The Noble Feast
  • The Humble Squid
  • The Swiftest Elk

If you’d like to take advantage of any new features, and you are on Guide Professional or Legacy, you can use the guidelines we provide with each new feature to manually implement that feature in your theme.

We will continue to support bug fixes for the standard legacy themes, and those will be pushed out automatically.

If you are currently using a standard legacy theme, we’d recommend taking a look at the Copenhagen theme. We believe that it has major improvements in usability and performance over our previous themes. One thing to note, once you switch to Copenhagen and publish your theme you will no longer be able to switch back to your legacy theme.

articles.name: Zendesk Talk - Default routes for IVR
articles.title: Zendesk Talk - Default routes for IVR
articles.body:
We've added a new route for you to use when configuring an IVR - the Default route. With the Default route you may configure different behaviours to be used in the event of customers failing to press a key or pressing incorrect keys. Default route options are the same as other routes such as forwarding the call to a group, voicemail, an external number or going to a different IVR menu level.

The Default route will be used when a customer fails to press a key or presses an incorrect key 3 times in a row. Current behaviour which is to disconnect the call in this circumstance remains if a Default route has not been configured.

To create a Default route simply select it as below.

The Default route will show up as the last route in a menu if it is configured.

Availability

If you are currently a Zendesk Talk customer on our Basic or Lite plans, you may request a free, 30-day “boost” to our Advanced plan to try IVR routing. Email us for more information.

"We can easily surface any unresolved tickets whenever we view any subscriber's account," says Allen. "I am really proud of our team...we're up to 12 now and Zendesk is a central part of the service we provide to our subscribers."

articles.name: Zendesk Support now supports SAML Custom User Fields
articles.title: Zendesk Support now supports SAML Custom User Fields
articles.body:
We are pleased to announce that Zendesk Support now supports SAML custom user fields for Single Sign-On.

In order to add custom user fields, you must first create the custom user field in Zendesk Support before creating it in your Identity provider (IdP). To do so in your Zendesk Support account, go to Settings > Manage > User Fields, and add a User Field. The field key needs to be identical to the field key you use in your IdP. When setting up the field name in your IdP it must start with ‘user_field_’ followed by the field key you used in Zendesk Support. For example, if your field key in Zendesk Support is “test”, your IdP field name should be ‘user_field_test’.

For more information on how to add custom user fields in Zendesk Support, see Adding customer user fields.

articles.name: Announcing the new trigger edit page
articles.title: Announcing the new trigger edit page
articles.body:
We're pleased to announce that we've got a new and improved interface for the trigger edit page. If the design looks familiar, it's because it's the same one we're already using on the macro edit page.

As of July 28, 2017, we've completed the phased rollout and it is now available to all accounts.

What's changed?

The interface has been redesigned for clarity and ease of use.

You can now add a description of the trigger. We know it isn't always easy to describe a trigger in the space allotted for a title (nor would you want a long title cluttering up the list view). So we gave you a place with more room to say what you need to say.

We removed the "permalink" feature that was a remnant of the days when you couldn't just copy and paste the URL from the browser. But now you'll be able to do that, so we freed up the space.

If you originally used commas to separate your tags, the commas will now be added to the end of the tag. To enter separate tags, please use spaces instead.

For more information on working with triggers, see Creating and managing triggers for ticket updates and notifications.

What's next?

What you can't see is that we also rebuilt the page "under the hood" to enable it to support new features reliably. Stay tuned for those!

Other rule edit pages (Views and Automations) will get the new-UI treatment in the future. Stay tuned for those too!
